message:
I am not interested in many activities other than reading and little video games and decided to learn to program, after researching, I found I should start with Computer Science to build strong foundations so, I decided to start with CS50 (from Harvard, which is available for free on edX and https://www.cs50.tv) and also, decided with short introductions to programming languages as needed during the course and afterwards from Derek Banas, TheNewBoson and other YouTubers.

I know that learning a lot of programming languages is not as good as knowing much about how to program things first, I mean that I will try different languages until I find myself good at one of them.

Do you think this will success or get me a real advantage in the future? Should I change something about *this, my curriculum*?

data.message:
[EDITED, check the replies to this comment]
If you like it and put in serious effort, it will be a TREMENDOUS advantage.
Check these links:
https://github.com/open-source-society/computer-science
https://github.com/mvillaloboz/open-source-cs-degree
https://www.google.com/about/careers/students/guide-to-technical-development.html

and in ~2 years or so, if you're still a student check this https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com

good luck

هو مش معني الجزء الاولاني من كلامك انك تفضل تدور علي انهي لغة افضلك 
لا المفروض تبتدي باي لغة (تكون high level language) واول متعرف انت عاوز تعمل ايه ساعتها هتلاقي لغة معينة هي اللي بتفرض نفسها عليك لان كل لغة بتقدم ميزة قوية عن اللغات التانية في مجال معين
بس عشان تبقي مبرمج كويس اليك الاتي :
اولا: شوف ال8 فيديوهات دول ساعتها هتعرف ايه افضل وسيلة للتدريب العملي
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPt2dINI2MIaNcU070HIAO8JWYBcafuyG
ثانيا: اتفرج علي حلقة كل يوم من ask developer ساعتها هتبقي ملم بالمجال بشكل بشع :) 
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJYBTsbldfv8tWX-KJMMmCO313pBXKL4l
ثالثا: اقترح عليك انك تبتدي في كورس عملي مع او بعد الكورس اللي انت فيه وتتعلم لغة معينة وتبتدي رحلة التدريب العملي :) لانه اهم حاجة هي العملي
رابعا: كويس ان معاك انجليزي حلو فعيش بقي علي كورسات البرمجة الانجليزي وخصوصا موقعين زي edx ,coursera
خامسا: ودي من احلي النصايح اللي اتقالتلي هي انك تقرا كتاب برمجة انجليزي من الالف لليه وهتلاقي سلسلة حلوة اسمها head first عاملين كتب في كذا لغة برمجة ممكن تبتدي بيهم (او بغيرهم برضواعادي)
سادسا: خليك متابع مجموعات زي دي و اسال باستمرار اديك عرفت المطرح :) 
واهم حاجة  ربنا يوفقك

Look at this coursera speciality 
https://www.coursera.org/specializations/java-programming
Simple and will help you to understand what's going on quickly plus it focuses in java which is very famous and most used .
In my opinion you can't study two different programming languages in the same time as you will get confused when it come to do same function with different syntax.
Other available option is python for everyone course in coursera which is very amazing with smart instructor and nice material.

Based on my own experience, none could tell me what is the best approach "for me". I had to keep trying till I managed. So I think the best advice is to follow what seems to be right from your own point of view, and you will tweak it on the go... With time, you will be seeking advice on much more narrow points, at this phase it will be easier to get proper advices from experienced people

CS50 is an *excellent* place to start. That will teach you the basics. Then you can expand your knowledge based on your preferences. FreeCodeCamp is another fantastic resource if you'd like to learn web development, it's totally free and has a great community where you can find help if you ever face problems. These alone will teach you much of what you need to know to start building software.
Also, if you need to pick a specific language, I'd recommend Python. It's so easy to get started with and is perfect for beginners, and can be used in almost any field.

I started cs50 about a year ago (prior i had very little programming experience, but was always interested in this field) , i finished cs50, then stoped for a bit then took on FreeCodeCamp, i finished almost all of the front end and 3 projects of the backend curriculum, all within a few months, im also taking computer science courses in college (started last august) so that is helping. CS50 was a very great advantage, i knew almost everything i got taught in the first semester, and if i didn't know it i knew how to know it.

Ok, so there are 2 paths to take:
1. The Foundations learning / University type approach, which is learning the proper foundations, history, and major theoretical concepts before diving into programming, which is of course the way to go if you want to be a professional, but you will learn a lot of stuff which might never be of use to you in the real world, but is important as a primer and is generally good know. (stuff like machine language, binary code, or even just the C programming language)

2. The quick course / certificate approach, which just dives right into practical programming right from the start in the programming language that you will end up using.

The first approach is recommended, if you are not in a hurry and have the time to learn about programming properly, in which case the CS50 course you mentioned is perfect. 
As for languages for this course, everyone should start with C, and then C++, as these languages will contain just about every concept you need to learn to move on to any other practical language in use today!
والنبي ياجماعة يعني اللي عامل share لكورس Java .. ماذا فعل من شر كي يبدأ حياته مع ال Java رفقا ..

بص.. الغات كلها عباره عن syntax . مش ده المهم.. اي لغه ممكن تتعلمها في يومين المهم انك تبقي عارف الاساسيات.
1. Server side vs client side langauge.
2. Object oriented programming
3. What is meant by libraray, how to include in ir project.
4. Advance topic like "patterns" u should know they exists, too early to use.
5. Understand differences between what is referred to as (environment) , whats is web, what is a servers -setup your own servers on ur own pc is a must-, desktop env. Etc.. U need to understand the eco system of each environment.
Then.....
Go build stuff.
Keep this rule infront of u:-
"If you cannot build it, you dont understand how it works".
If u see any project that you like, try to build it/clone ur self..  By time u will be able to build anything :)
Good luck
